content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Don't watch any LPs of it, most of them are god awful face cam LPs that are really just man-children making fun of something they don't understand or take time to understand for "lulz".Long Live The Queen is appears to be a visual novel with a political skin, but it's much more of a political game that's skinned like a Visual Novel.  You take control of Elodie, a 14 year old princess of Nova, tasked with becoming queen after her mother died or unusual circumstances. However Nova is not a very safe nation, their are many dangers around the corner and something as innocent as chocolate can and will be the death of you.The game is very difficult as many has stated before, and if you save to much you'll not have enough time to train in stats you need for certain events, so that adds an extra layer of challenge, which is why only completing a single run though and several failed ones is an achievement for me. One of the things that make's the game very interesting is all the skills you can practice, you're never going to be able to complete every skill, and the game will check every skill several times and will have "big" moments where the skills will be very handy, which adds great replay-ability. However of the games short comings is the repetitiveness, the intro is always the same and the events are always the same, just with new solutions but it can be very boring at times. The art isn't particularly amazing either, most if it looks like it was made in a generator of sorts and doesn't look natural, and almost none of the faces give off any emotion and sometimes the dialogue barely does either..I can't tell if Josyln is suppose to happy, dead or just emotionally dead half the time.As a whole, the game is a good "Visual Novel Strategy Game" that kept me hooked and made me come back every time the DAMN BANDITS KILLED ME.

												TL;DR Review at bottomGamepay and Story For gameplay it dose what it's supposed to do as a Simulation/Strategy game, with lots of choices that can make you better or wores. With classes that make you're princess better at whatever you have chosen, But if her mood becomes a probelm you can make it better by letting her play after school. Her mood can help with some classes or make it harder, try to make the best of her moods.For the story I don't have a lot... Because I haven't beat the game yet. but I got far to at lest see most of it, as a young girl try her best to make things better for the good of all people you see a lot of story as you meet new people and see old friends. But sometimes you see some of the games evil characters who are mostly just ?????.Main Character Let's start with our lovey princess elodie, Even if I haven't beating the game I still love this character the most. she has a heart as big as the moon, has love for her people, and has a mind open to what's going on in her world. but I sometimes feel odd about her, When her mood is sad she will have a sad look on her face wich makes me feel in a way sad for her, When her mood is angry she have a ???? off look as if she going to slap my face hard, But the worest is when she is afraid... she will have a face the looks as if i'm about to her in the bedroom (and it dosent help that theres a bed that can have two people in it behind her.....) But still a Very cute and lovey character <3Achievements Most of these achievements make you have to play through a lot of the story to get, but some are esay to get, one you can get very early in the game. Thats really all i have to say about achievements, I didn't play this game for them, I just played to see elodie...Cards and Badges This game has a lot of cards to get, but it's not that bad... in fact it's fun to get badges in any games! I wish I had a Long Live The Queen Badge, I haven't see any of them yet. The Cards have some pics from the game, I don't always trade, but when I do, I trade cards.TL;DRGame of Thrones if it was a visual novel.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												"Putting all the sick people together? Won't that make them die even faster?"- the girl who thought that pushing an arrow through her the rest of the way would save her lifeLong Live the Queen is a fun little visual novel where the main object is to... well, live long.You will probably fail a lot. It's okay, though! Half of the fun of the game is finding all of the different ways you can die. The other half is being a ruthless dictator/pretty princess that rules with an iron fist. Or possibly with lots of magic lightning bolts. But either way, it won't be fun for your enemies. Provided you didn't die, I mean.The game also deserves credit for having a very nicely realized world, with lots of background detail that adds to its charm. The geography, history, and characterization all add up to complex land with all kinds of variables that will change your game.Seriously, though, this game is addicting. All of the different paths you can take, all of the different deaths, and, true to visual novel form, all of the different possible endings (and that's aside from the death ones!).Will you die by magic? Will you be shot? Will you eat the dreaded chocolates (answer: yes)? Or, against all odds, will you survive long enough for your coronation, and live happily ever after (possibly as an evil minion, if you play your cards tight).

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												I tried a few runs of this game, but it got tiring and predictable.  So I took a break from it for a week, and it still felt predictable!  Maybe that has to do with it being a life sim, where direction of the game depends entirely on success/failure of certain events based on the skills you've chosen to train up to when the event approaches.  The problem is that it's the same event everytime, so the game is repetitive to absolution.Don't buy the game - you can watch someone else play it on youtube, but even that gets boring.  The writing is terrible, and music isn't anything special, and the graphics are still images with no animation.  The drawings are cutsie anime you can find anywhere.Fun for maybe an hour, but it has no replayability and the game simulates difficulty by arbitrarily failing you at every moment.Skills range from 0 - 100, and most things require 50+ skill to succeed, so the replayability lies in how you construct your princess and finding out which skills are essential to avoid death in the first place.So yeah, not worth what I paid.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/long-live-the-queen-game-review/Many of you may just look at Long Live the Queen and pass it off as some “girly anime game”. I too thought that the game looked a bit silly, but I was surprised by just how enjoyable it is. It’s almost a masterpiece, which is not something I’d say too easily.Long Live the Queen is essentially a visual/interactive novel, but it goes a lot more in-depth in terms of interactivity that most visual novels do. You’re tasked with getting the main character, Elodie, to her coronation as Queen of Nova without getting killed. Although the game seems incredibly childish, it’s actually quite morbid. There are several deaths that Elodie can run into, with my first one being an arrow to the side, of which my “battlefield medicine” skill was not high enough for me to survive the incident.The other half of the game, aside from making good choices, is made up of skills. Elodie can learn a variety of skills. It’s actually a bit overwhelming, the amount of different skills that can be learned. Every week, you have the choice of choosing two classes to take during that specific week, with each skill having its own class. Each of these skills is a part of a group of skills, which is a part of another group of skills. For example, the “Social” skill tree is made up of three skills: Royal Demeanor, Conversation, and Expression. Each of these breaks down even further, into three “sub-skills”. Expression breaks down into: “Decoration”, “Instrument”, and “Voice”. The four major categories for skills are: Social, Intellectual, Physical, and Mystical.During the development of the game’s story, you’ll encounter various “skill checks” during the dialogue portions of the story. Passing a skill check is always good, as it progresses the story in a positive way (and can help prevent your death). Failing a skill check usually does not matter too much, but in some scenarios, failing a skill check can actually cause your death.There’s also another major aspect to this game, that being Elodie’s mood. Her mood changes based on what happens during the storyline of the game and the choice you make at the end of the week as to what Elodie will do during the weekend. There are four sets of moods in the game, with two different emotions in each: Afraid — Angry, Depressed — Cheerful, Yielding — Willful, and Lonely — Pressured. Whichever mood is dominant determines the skill bonuses for that specific week (each “turn” in the game is another week). Each mood gives a bonus and a penalty to certain skills. The “depressed” mood gives a bonus to expression and animal handling, but a penalty to royal demeanor, conversation, and athletics, with all other skills remaining neutral. This can be used to greatly improve any of Elodie’s skills, depending on her mood that week.Long Live the Queen was a very, very fun experience. If I had to criticize the game, I’d note that the player has no idea which moods correspond to which skills in terms of bonuses and penalties (until you have that specific mood), so the use of a wiki is almost essential. I prefer to go at it and learn myself, but I could understand one using a wiki to avoid getting penalties when attending classes. Also, unless you use a wiki, you’ll have no idea when a certain skill will be required anytime during the story. You may get the hang of it after playing the game for an extended period of time though. Highly recommended!

												I find this game incredibly frustrating. You get killed repeatedly with no warning, and often without being able to properly appraise how you could have avoided it, or even which skills might have let you avoid it. There's really nothing to this game except playing it over and over again until you learn what precise combo of skills lets you become who you want to become, and it overall just feels like an incredible time-sink with very little reward for the player.Example - I trained to be a badass magical warrior, with high Swordsmanship, Magical attack, and Magical defence. I then lost a magical duel because I'd never studied flower arranging. I could not have known that was coming, except by doing all that, dying, and then starting -completely over- and training my princess very slightly differently.This is the bulk of Long Live the Queen's gameplay.

I really wanted to, and maybe a little too much.I read so many nice reviews and knowing what kind of game it was I thought "wow, this is just MY kind of game!"I might have anticipated playing the game too much, i admit it. number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												I'm a big fan of the type of games and don't get me wrong, I'm not bashing the game or say it isn't entertaining (I'll probably play it again, once the bitterness of dying because I don't own a dog while being the equivalent of an archmage subsides).The thing is, when I pick up a game like this one I expect to have fun discovering the multiple endings it contains, not trying my hardest not to die and then find out which ending I end up with.I understand the concept of the game is to "live different lives, learning from last time's demise", but when I actually played it just felt like a game of memorization; the story is kind of generic and there doesn't exist much foreshadowing in it.There should be something in the narrative that tells me certain skills might be necessary in the future, but instead it's just a game of trial and error, which becomes tiring after a number of playthroughs.My biggest gripe is that most events happen out of the blue, and as the story progresses they need bigger and bigger skill checks. The problem with this is that if you neglected said skill (or group of) you're toast; you were practically dead 10 turns ago, but you just have to keep playing until the game decides to kill you.Seeing the tweaks that have been made to the game, I believe that something could be done to help the gameplay without straying from the concept of the game. For example, starting a new game from a previous death while inheriting a part of your previous skills would make sense, while also giving it genuine replay value (other than having a list of "things to study by turn X to not die").This is a game for the hard-core and can actually be pretty entertaining if you enjoy that "grinding", but I wouldn't recommend it for everyone because of said reasons.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												LLtQ is a good game. Good, but not the best. It suffers from some repetition in that a good portion of the time you invest will be spent attempting to figure out which combinations of choices you make will lead to each ending (and avoid death in the process). The save feature cuts down on this a bit, but if you haven't had previous experience with this type of game, then you are going to be doing a lot of backtracking and starting over. On the other hand, if you know the trick to playing this sort of resource management game, you can easily earn your crown with a half-dozen deaths or less, and in just a couple of hours. The multiple endings add replay value, but you still face the same issues mentioned before. I found the art, UI, and story to be sufficiently engaging, but the music felt somewhat generic, and the $9.99 price tag seems a tad high. I would say buy this when it is on sale for maximum bang for your buck. In the meantime, if you still want to play a game like LLtQ, try the Princess Maker games. They are much more in-depth and have an RPG element to them as well.Overall, I give this game a 7/10 - good enough to own and play, bad enough to be a little picky as to when you get your copy, and put it off in favour of better games.

												This game is quite pretty, yes, but it's essentially a shorter watered-down version of one of the Princess Maker games. While it was fun for a few playthroughs, I found myself constantly comparing it to PM. It lacked the many wide and varied options of that game, the only way to raise your character, the Princess Elodie was to bring her up to become a queen, while in PM games, you can name her anything, and raise anything from a ♥♥♥♥♥ to the queen of Hell, or send your girl off on quests. You also only get one year in LLTQ, as opposed to the 8 years of game time in a round of PM. The other obvious difference between the two games is that in LLTQ, Elodie can die. And she will die. On most playthroughs.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												LLTQ is not an easy game to review. I really enjoyed the combination of seemingly light-minded Princess Maker-like character development and brutal, merciless medieval (fantasy) politics, but the problems I had with the game mechanics overshadowed the complex storylines. Maybe it's a tradition for these type of games to be extremely grindy, but the constant need of either reloading savestates or incredible amount of trial-and-error drains the fun out from gameplay. For the record, I had fun playing through the game first five-six times, until I realized it wouldn't get me anywhere unless I made a perfect plan before starting instead of trying to react to whatever was happening.)The game has beautiful art and lots of interesting plotlines, but you have to go through the same initial events over and over again to experience most of them. In other words, the overrall gameplay becomes more and more boring while you're searching for sparks of undiscovered content (in action games this would work, but in LLTQ you'll just end up starting over because you didn't know what skills you need in whatever situation beforehand). Still, it's probably the best game of its kind out right now, and someone with past experience with this genre probably won't find the mechanics so incredibly arduous!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												“Long Live The Queen”:  5.5/10After finishing the game, I reflected on the game and my choices. I am not particularly happy with the outcome, but I didn’t necessarily pick the best options, either. Still, this game should come down to dialog and choices, and the game doesn’t do a great job of that.Gameplay consists of deciding what you’ll study for the week, managing your mood (which, in turn affects how well you learn things via studying), and responding to events (which occur after studying). You get two things to study each week, and get 40 weeks to outfit your potential queen the way you want to (meaning, you get 80 choices on what to study). I sought out to make my queen an interesting one: a falcon-handling, flattery-using, lonely queen that ignores any attempt at courtship. After all, if you give me interesting and/or “silly” options, I’m going to want to investigate them and see how they play out. That’s not to say that I completely ignored important stats, such as history and economics, but that I wanted to make my character how *I* wanted, not how the developers wanted. And this works…sort of. While you get random events that use some of the lesser important characteristics, chances are, you’re *going* to have to utilize a specific skill. And, if you don’t have it increased to a certain point, you’re going to fail, and likely get game over. If you’re going to give us choice, let us have true choice; this is what bums me out the most in the game. Some of the choices are badly done as well. Take, for instance, a pair of chocolates I receive from a commoner. The text forebodes that the box is questionable (“it’s far too well done for a commoner to have made…”), and tells you *before* you make the decision that you either pass or fail a poison check. Why before?!? You’ve explicitly told me that I shouldn’t eat them. Other choices don’t seem to have any impact on the story, either; one particular knowledge check I passed and knew more about the situation, but then I promptly re-loaded the game to see what would happen when I failed, and I came to the same conclusion without any difference, other than that I didn’t know that a family member did something-or-other. While I’m not certain that all choices are such as this, but it’s disappointing to know that some things that you do don’t really matter.SPOILERS: Some of the “choices” aren’t really choices at all, either; you really can’t leave the castle. If you decide to partake in a parade, you either have to have a *very* high specific stat, or you die. Want to participate in an archery contest? Better have it almost maxed, or you fail, and get called out to a duel to the death. Want to visit your relatives? Better hope that you’ve got high reflexes, or you’re taking an arrow to the heart. I understand that there’s got to be some resemblance of a story, but I want to play *my* way, not yours. On the last series of events, I had to save before my decision, and reload it at *least* seven times to barely make it out alive, and that took the king / my father sacrificing himself to the killer of my mother / queen. This basically means that you *have* to get specific stats increased to be able to avoid a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ending. Another thing that puzzled me was that there was a couple of instances (I’d estimate five out of forty events) having to do with the royal treasury (“should we hire more troops? Etc.), but there was no form of currency to manage, nor was there any indication upon reloading and choosing differently did it make any impact whatsoever. Illusion of choice is something I am more-or-less okay with, but not when it’s this obvious. END SPOILERSComing into the game, I was under the presumption that it would be largely dialog-driven. This really isn’t the case. Yes, it is present, but not as much as I had hoped; it felt like the game was 75% choosing what I would be studying. I would have really liked to see the game explore more relationships and dialog (although, to be fair, [SPOILERS] my choices did rather exclude marrying anyone, and letting my father die (it was that or game over…)[SPOILERS], so it very well could be different in other routes of the game).In terms of replayability, I spent two hours on the game, start to finish, with perhaps 10 minutes of afk / loading. Because of the relatively ♥♥♥♥♥♥ outcome I got, I was *kind of* interested in playing the game again…but I decided against it. I don’t really think that I’ll be replaying the game again. For a regularly $10 game, I don’t think that two hours for $10 is a good deal. Despite these flaws, I will say that I did sit down and play the game from start to finish in one sitting, which isn’t something most games are capable of. And before starting this review, I did have a higher opinion of the game before I starting articulating my thoughts (initially, I gave it a reluctant 6.5/10). Overall, I’ll remember this game as a game that had great potential, yet didn’t fully realize what could have been.I wouldn’t say that this is a bad game, but I wouldn’t say it’s a particularly good game, either. Considering all of the above, I wouldn’t recommend the game, but if you are interested, I would only recommend it at $2.49.

												Today I'm writing a review for "Long Live the Queen"This little game is an interesting blend of things I grew up with, visual novels of course. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												"How hard could this anime garbage be," I whispered, downloading what I assumed would be a relatively short foray into the world of moeblobs and banal love interests. I carefully craft my day to revolve around nothing but birds, military, and swords. Twenty minutes later I am dead because the game did not take pity on my attempts to be a humorously uncouth ruler. No, instead it bent me over backwards and gave me a cruel reminder of why you should save frequently, no matter what you're playing. Long Live The Queen will kill you. You will reload, swearing and sweating, furiously trying to pour your actions into learning what you hope will save your life the next skill check that rolls by. You still die. You die and you die and the game won't stop, even when you're sobbing in front of your keyboard furiously trying to come up with a strategy that will keep you alive at least long enough to get crowned queen.I wanted to put my face through a window after my fifth attempt to not get murdered. Hardcore royalty sim masquerading beneath some Puella Magica BS. 11/10, will need therapy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I was skeptical at first - I never played something like this before, whatever "genre" this may be - but from the start this game was very intresting. It takes a lot of strategic thinking to get a good ending, and it's pretty difficult achieving one on your first tries; nonetheless, i found myself quite addicted with it. Even when I wasn't playing, sometimes, I started wondering wich path could I try to avoid death - skills to learn, in what order, choices to make - and that's good, it means the game is entrataining. The graphics may look frilly, but it's nice to look at it for long times - considering that you'll spend most of your game time looking at the skill-review screen to decide what to learn. The concept is good, and so is the plot; pretty much everyone could be planning your death, and most of the time you won't even know what you will be facing. The storyline also manages to surprise with sudden twists, so every skill may come handy.  I have already achieved two different endings, but I'll definetly play more to discover new ones. Moreover, after dying many times, you kinda feel good for the main character when finally you get to the ending xD I figure that once familiar with the mechanics and once used to save and load at specific points of the story, breaking through the endings is surely easier, but that's not a downside, actually. All considered, I think this may be a nice choice if you never played anything similar before and you feel you'd like to try.

Moreover, after dying many times, you kinda feel good for the main character when finally you get to the ending xD I figure that once familiar with the mechanics and once used to save and load at specific points of the story, breaking through the endings is surely easier, but that's not a downside, actually. All considered, I think this may be a nice choice if you never played anything similar before and you feel you'd like to try.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												"How hard could this anime garbage be," I whispered, downloading what I assumed would be a relatively short foray into the world of moeblobs and banal love interests. I carefully craft my day to revolve around nothing but birds, military, and swords. Twenty minutes later I am dead because the game did not take pity on my attempts to be a humorously uncouth ruler. No, instead it bent me over backwards and gave me a cruel reminder of why you should save frequently, no matter what you're playing. Long Live The Queen will kill you. You will reload, swearing and sweating, furiously trying to pour your actions into learning what you hope will save your life the next skill check that rolls by. You still die. You die and you die and the game won't stop, even when you're sobbing in front of your keyboard furiously trying to come up with a strategy that will keep you alive at least long enough to get crowned queen.I wanted to put my face through a window after my fifth attempt to not get murdered. Hardcore royalty sim masquerading beneath some Puella Magica BS. 11/10, will need therapy.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Who didn't want to be a princess at somepoint in his/her life? ;) This game fulfills that fantasy in visual-novel style, while still enabling a significant amount of interactivity and decission making. You might be a little overwhelmed in the first playthrough by the amount of skill-sets, but you will soon get the hang of it. It is good that the game gives you feedback whenever a skill passed or failed to adapt you strategy for your next playthrough. Therefore I recommend also to save often and in different slots, because you will run into "dead ends" if you level up the wrong skills.I also like the mood system. Different moods give you bonusses for different skills, e.g. "Depression" boosts artistic skills, why "Angry" boosts military skills. I really like this system, because it justifies each "mood". There are also different outfits to unlock which also boost certain skills. Also a nice way to customize your charakter.The story is well written, but it's a little difficult to get to understand the different realms and relations between the charakters.Another motivating aspect is in a "completionist" way to unlock as many "deaths" or other achievements as possible. The "skip" function helps to try different approaches in a quick way.

The images and scenes described in the game plays through my head like a movie while I play, and the game lets me use my imagination instead of showing me every single detail.Do you like visual novels or rpgs? Take this for a test ride, you'll surely have some fun with it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												This is one of the more compelling games I've played recently. A sprawling, chaotic choose-your-own-adventure with labyrinthine plot strands that can change and evolve in surprisingly subtle ways depending on the choices you make and the skills you level up.It's also a damn difficult game. Having played through about 10 times I have only successfully completed it (i.e. reached my coronation) ONCE, and even then I was forced to make some pretty douchey decisions to ensure my own survival. However the challenge is what will compel you to start again and again, trying different strategies and skill progressions.Slight negatives - some of the plinky plonky piano music will get on your♥♥♥♥♥♥after about an hour, and I believe the game has a noticeable bias in favour of certain skills (looking at you Lumen and Court Manners) however I cannot confirm this as there's still so much of this game I haven't seen despite so many playthroughs. Also as this is a "visual novel", the genre of which normally has manga-ish overtones, another aspect of the game has you dressing up a 14 year old girl in different garments to boost certain skills. Mostly this is fine, but a few outfits are a bit ♥♥♥♥ing dodgy in my opinion (again, looking at you Lumen).Overall, well happy with my purchase, and still playing now. Long Live the Queen!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												I have played this game for a little over an hour and a half, and thus far I have been:shot by an arrow (twice),poisoned, andstabbed by an angry noble in a duel.This game is addicting in the way Choose Your Own Adventure books are addicting; when you make the wrong choice, you want to go back and try again. Unfortunately, unlike those books you can't necessarily just go back to the last choice you made and start over; some events are the result of choices you made much eariler in the game. (Hint: frequent saves on multiple save files are your very, very best friend.) This game also benefits from the reasonably engaging story line (drama and intrigue galore; shades of Game of Thrones), stats system based on education (appealing to my dorkiest tendencies), and general adorableness even when your princess is skewered on somebody's rapier. It's a bit like a visual novel and RPG meshed in an oddly endearing way. I'm a little frustrated with my inability to progress beyond a certain point, but that's my fault for not saving more often!TL;DR: Fun for OCD nihilists everywhere!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												I was excited that Steam had this game. I didn't think I'd find anything like it on Steam. I love dating and/or growing up simulation games, like Princess Maker 2, and RE:Alistair++, but you usually don't see them around much).Update for Steam awards and more detail.The game is in a similar vein to games like Princess Maker 2 and Spirited Heart. You spend time raising your combination of Elodie's many stats in hopes of keeping her alive (and as queen) until her coronation. Unless you're looking at a guide, you're going to die. A few times. There are many parts of the story where you have to meet certain skill checks (one of the achievements is for finding 11 ways to die. This means "poisoned", "stabbed", "drowned", not stabbed by 11 different people or missing 11 skill checks to drown.There's two really cool things to that, though: (1) they always tell you where you failed (or even partially pass) a skill check (not all fails kill you), so it adds to the replayability because you're curious about what you missed. But, it also doesn't give the exact numbers (IIRC), so you might not know exactly how much higher you need to make the skill. (2) For most of the situations that could kill you, there are either ways to avoid the situation altogether, or multiple ways to pass the scenario.For example:  Based on a skill check, you can get a choice on whether or not to eat poisoned food. If you fail that check, you don't get a choice--Elodie chooses to eat it. But, based on another skill check, she can be prevented from eating it. If that skill check fails, though, she eats it and gets poisoned. But, THEN there's a check for a different skill for you to counteract the poison.This means you definitely have to put some points in a few areas you might not think of, but it still gives you a lot of room to play Elodie as an overall character that you like. Want Elodie to be a pacifist? You don't need to know archery, but you'll probably want to know medicine.For that, I decided to suggest a category to nominate LLtQ in: "Replay to Win". I wanted it to be a category for those types of games where you usually start over to get ahead. Often times, those are visual novels, or games like Dead or Alive Xtreme 2 (where you have to repeat the 2-week vacation).

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												As a girl, I'm supposed to like these kind of games. Well, I've got something to tell you: this is no child's play.You have no idea how many people would like to see a 14-years-old pink-haired soon-to-be-queen princess dead.It's almost impossible to win on your first gameplay. You have to deal with Elodie's emotions very well. You also have know which skills you want to train beforehand so you can manipulate her feelings and earn bonus.I don't usually play visual novels, but this one is special. While it doesn't have any dark secret to be found at the end of the story, it sure can surprise you. It's quite difficult to predict what's going to happen next, even after some playthroughs.It's -not- a date simulator, and there's little to no romance in this game - of course you'll marry someone eventually, butthat's not important.The best part is that you can actually create your own personality for Elodie in each gameplay. There are a lot of options that cover almost every type of person you want her to be. I recommend you to have a couple of saves of the same gameplay, but some weeks apart. You never know when you're going to get busted out of nowhere.But mostly I recommend this game. If you bought it with the Humble Bundle and still did not give it a try, you should.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												I got the game in a bundle without even knowing what it was, and I'm so glad that I did. I'm a meticulous person at heart, and organization is a personal passion. So when I started this game, with branching paths all over the place and all different unlockable story components and opportunities, I was in heaven. I've got a Word document saved right now, detailing the different paths and the effects of succeeding or failing each test. It's far from complete, and I'm certain there will be hours and hours of additional entertainment as I seek out the deaths, epilogues, and achievements that still elude me as I fill in more of my ever-growing chart of options.Be aware, there's no such thing as a "perfect" game. I nearly drove myself mad attempting to raise stats in such a way that I passed every test. You simply cannot, and I think it's for the better. The game forces you to choose what knowledge and opportunities are most important to you and give up the rest or simply save it for another playthrough.The artwork and different outfits are cute, and I appreciated that aspect of the game. However, if you do buy the game (and if you're anything like me, I hope you do because you'll have a blast), make sure you're doing it for the strategy and story element, since those are what truly make the game something special.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Do you have what it takes to stay alive? Probably not. Will it tick you off to no end?Probably. Will it be fun? Only if you're masochistic. As it turns out, I am apparently masochistic. This game is extremely addictive, with a relatively simple yet alarmingly improbable premise: survive to your fifteenth birthday. You'll face traitorous relatives, violent monsters, unpredictable magic, court room drama, espionage, and murder. There are more ways to die in this game than to survive. You'll get at least four hours play out of it just trying to survive one playthrough. It's the kind of game that will make you try and try again, and the various outcomes and differences in decision can drastically alter the storyline. Ergo, while certain events over the course of playthrough will stay the same, the end result of differing choices will likely be new to you long into becoming familiar with the game. All in all, Long Live The Queen is a fun (annoying) little game that will provide hours of entertainment (frustration). It has great art, a quirky storyline, and is perfect for visual novel fans. 8/10.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Long Live the Queen is an odd title, but very in its own niche. If you can get passed the "anime" aesthetic (which is more "moe" than anything else), you find yourself in a heavily political fantasy game. Every class you take to build your skill tree is important to your survival as well as the relationships you build in your own kingdom and on. What may seem daunting and a little frustrating at first, you'll come to find that some deaths are avoidable, even without having the proper skills (such as choosing not to follow the shady figure in the woods). Events are also not random, so the more you play, the lower the difficulty gauge. Overall, I find this little gemstone to be alright for what it is. It's not a horrible time-waster, and it's pleasing enough on the eye. However I would reccommend only getting this game while it's on sale ($5 or less), as it's short and does not have as much replay value as one would hope.

Unfortunately, unlike those books you can't necessarily just go back to the last choice you made and start over; some events are the result of choices you made much eariler in the game. (Hint: frequent saves on multiple save files are your very, very best friend.) This game also benefits from the reasonably engaging story line (drama and intrigue galore; shades of Game of Thrones), stats system based on education (appealing to my dorkiest tendencies), and general adorableness even when your princess is skewered on somebody's rapier. It's a bit like a visual novel and RPG meshed in an oddly endearing way. I'm a little frustrated with my inability to progress beyond a certain point, but that's my fault for not saving more often!TL;DR: Fun for OCD nihilists everywhere!

Posted: April 4, 2015
												This is only what I thought of the gme you can skip to the pros and cons at the bottom if you'd like.Opinion: How do you know a game is good? When even though it angers and infuriates you, you still keep coming back for more and that's exactly what this game does. As of yet I have died many times from various things that seem innocent at the time but killed me later and every time I only get more furious with the game, for example please tell me how a Decoration skill matters in a magical duel to the death? But it's also for this reason that the game is so good, there are so many interlocking events that you will find yourself eager to replay it again and again with each time trying a new method to see how far it gets you. To put it in perspective there are so many skills and events that the game's wiki couldn't make a walkthrough of it. This game will make you embrace your inner paranoia and I loved it.Pros:Extreme replayabilityEvery action has a consequenceDifferent and interactive storylinesTreats player as intelligentThrows the player right into the gameExtremely good funCons:Soundtrack could have flowed better with the gameOutfits for the character were kind of annoyingSome of the deaths and skills were frustrating (the Decoration example to name one)Confusingly large number of characters.Never explains what mood affects each skillSteep learning curveFinal verdict: Worth a buy  8/10Long Live The Queen!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Long Live The Queen is by no means a bad game, but it does have a few problems. The biggest one is the fact that the game is incredibly short. It only lasts about a month, which is by no means enough time to accomplish much. It also gives you way too many skills to raise in such a short amount of time, and considering that there's really only one ending, raising the necessary skills to pass all the skill checks at that point causes your other skills to suffer, which, in turn, causes you to miss out on multiple events due to not having enough points in the right skill. Multiple playthroughs or a walkthrough is needed in order to know what happens when and what skills you need. All that being said, the visual novel style of the game is quite nice and the skills checks do add an interesting gameplay element to the game. In my own personal opinion, though, Princess Maker 2 an older, but better game of similar design that succeeds where LLTQ fails. If you're wanting to try out Long Live The Queen, then by all means do, but I'd wait until it's on sale.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I was skeptical at first - I never played something like this before, whatever "genre" this may be - but from the start this game was very intresting. It takes a lot of strategic thinking to get a good ending, and it's pretty difficult achieving one on your first tries; nonetheless, i found myself quite addicted with it. Even when I wasn't playing, sometimes, I started wondering wich path could I try to avoid death - skills to learn, in what order, choices to make - and that's good, it means the game is entrataining. The graphics may look frilly, but it's nice to look at it for long times - considering that you'll spend most of your game time looking at the skill-review screen to decide what to learn. The concept is good, and so is the plot; pretty much everyone could be planning your death, and most of the time you won't even know what you will be facing. The storyline also manages to surprise with sudden twists, so every skill may come handy.  I have already achieved two different endings, but I'll definetly play more to discover new ones. Moreover, after dying many times, you kinda feel good for the main character when finally you get to the ending xD I figure that once familiar with the mechanics and once used to save and load at specific points of the story, breaking through the endings is surely easier, but that's not a downside, actually. All considered, I think this may be a nice choice if you never played anything similar before and you feel you'd like to try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Although I am usually NOT a fan of Roguelike perma-death / Start over type games (& over, and over, and over, etc), Long Live the Queen is too perfectly charming not to like.It is a very well designed game. You learn as you go, how to avoid certain traps by focusing on learning certain skills before others. It took me a few short-lived (for the Queen) run-thrus to get the hang of the simple system. Or rather, to see what choices I should have made early on. But really, you're going to be doing that throughout the game anyway.It's not as easy as I thought it would be. But you start caring about the little Queen and you really want her to succeed....or live for that matter. And keeping her alive is no easy task. At least not for me. The dialog options are good & you make choices that really matter & that have potentially severe consequences. IMO the writing is very tight in this area. It's one of the things I liked most. It has slight RPG elements, in that you decide what she will learn. The classes you choose for her will increase her skill in specific areas, all of which are vitally important to her continued existence, and all of which will affect your dialog options at some point throughout the entire game. It's all tied together very nicely.So if you are a fan of games with a decent story, or a fan of Roguelikes in general, I recommend you buy this little gem and enjoy the heck out of it. If you like Visual Novels you will enjoy this....though Queen is a LOT more interactive than most VN's as it is an actual game first.It's a fun little game to spend time with & I certainly encourage everyone to try it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												The game is fun, but very short and severely lacking. I beat it in less than a day.The game is basically like one of those old DOS command lines, but with a GUI. Instead of typing, for example/attackyou would click a dialog on screen that reads"Attack!"The story is mildly interesting, and mildly emotional. The dialogue gives you a good idea of what is going on. You can train Elodie in different skills. In one part of the game (minor spoilers, doesn't affect story) somebody sends you a box of chocolates that is poisoned. If Elodie is proficient in divination she will notice a bad omen and you will have the option of not eating the chocolates. If she has proficient knowledge in poison, medicine, or herbs she will be able to heal after ingesting the poison. If Elodie hasn't been trained in any of these things she will eat the chocolates and die.I really wish the game would continue past coronation. It is very fun and entertaining, some of the battles and dialogue is really intense and gets you going. It stops short, however. It would also be cool if there was more visual feedback. Instead of:"A fierce battle rages on. elodie makes lots of explosions with her magic and bodies fly everywhere" it would be cool if there were animations that showed these things happening. Sometimes the battles can be difficult to visualize and it takes you out of the moment.That being said the game is very fun to play and I definitely recommend it for those who like command line or RPG games. It is very fun and I enjoyed it very much.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												So. Many. CHOICES! D:There's a massive amount of skills, and if that wasn't enough their experience gaining is affected by mood. And then there are certain scenarios where you really wouldn't expect a certain skill to be important and so you get screwed over.The only experiences I've had in visual novels before this were everlasting summer and katawa shoujo. I expected this to be another fairly simple game with only a few scenario choices every now and then. Boy was I wrong. What makes this game so darn hard is the overwhelming amount of choice.There are so many things that can have different outcomes it is hard to try and avoid one problem without getting yourself into another.I won't say I 'recommend' this game because of all the rage (and headaches from thinking of strategies) it has caused me, but it looks like its got a decent of story if you're willing to bear with the pain. (since I -have- to recommend or not recommend, I chose recommend because the game itself isn't bad)I haven't played dark souls, but if it causes you a lot of rage from unexpected bad endings then I'd agree with that similarity.--UPDATE--I have now got all the achievements, which means I have experienced the majority of the content the game has to offer. However, even now there are certain epilogue stories and minor plot texts I have not achieved, but for these I just looked them up online.I mainly play VNs for the story (and I didn't want to spend loads of time trying [and probably failing] to get the different routes) so I used the debug tools to get different routes and endings. While I like the content that is there, the game makes it quite hard to achieve certain routes without the tools. There is certain content most people simply won't experience because its so hard to meet the requirements for.So the game's biggest selling factor is also its biggest weakness- the large amount of choices and variables.If you are too lazy to even mess about with debug tools but would be interested in learning some more lore/plot about the game then you could look here: http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VisualNovel/LongLiveTheQueenHOWEVER, THAT LINK DOES CONTAIN SPOILERS.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												“Long Live the Queen” is a life simulation game that’s reminiscent towards games like “Princess Maker” in Japan.Primarily, the main goal is to have Elodie, the princess that the player has to “raise” and help her survive wars, potential threats, and ward off unwanted suitors before she could become queen at fifteen years old, who is considered as a legal adult in this time period.There are different classes Elodie could take – such as, conversations, royal demeanor, animal handling, history, economics, faith, military, athletics, agility, and much much more! The more classes she takes, the more her skills will rise. The more her skills rise, the better she can understand certain conversations to progress the story along. Of course, it’s completely up to the player on what kind of queen Elodie could be just based on the choices made alone. There really isn’t an end to the choices to choose from!One of the main things that brings people to this game is not just what kind of queen she would be but if she’s going to survive long enough to become a queen. There are various ways to die in this game and each one is actually part of the achievements – which is a unique thing about it since most games would try to prevent that from happening.There is a way to avoid dying, of course, but the player has to make sure that her skill set for certain actions are pretty much almost completely filled up.Another unique thing about this game is the mood system. For every mood that she is, there’s a penalty and there’s a bonus. Certain moods help boost up skills for whatever class the player chooses for her and others, well, not so much. There’s actually a penalty if the player makes Elodie take the wrong classes for a certain mood she’s in.There are outfits the player can unlock, so long as that particular subject is pretty well-balanced. These outfits help boost up that particular subject, especially if she’s in a war, a tournament, or at the gala, although more often than not, they’re just there to change up from her boarding school uniform.If Elodie does manage to survive to coronation, there are epilogues afterwards based on the choices that the player makes. They’re the literal result of what happens based on the player’s choices and decisions as a young fourteen year old girl trying to become a Queen.Not only does the epilogues come in what happened to Elodie and her subjects (if they’re involved in any way), but they come in beautiful drawings that’s similar to stained glass on the castle walls.But what do I think of it? I really enjoyed it! It’s a lot of fun and it’s fun to try to get the different endings and different deaths. There’s actually a checklist within the game itself to try to get all the achievements, deaths, and different epilogue stained glasses to try to vary the game experience up.While it does seem that the endings are endless, there are a few problems.Going over the game over and over, eventually, it starts to become extremely repetitive. Sometimes new menus and new choices pop up which could lead to different endings/results but eventually, the player might have to pass by that same choice and those same scenes again just to get to the choices that the player has to deviate from.It’s a little bit of a bore but there is the option to skip the text so it’s really not that bad. Once new text pops up, though, it stops so the player can read it. There is the option to go back and re-do the choices but it doesn’t work all the time, so be sure you know what you’re doing in terms of choices.The writing for the political intrigue is pretty basic for a life simulation game but, honestly, I’m not sure if that’s really a complaint or not. On one hand, the player would know exactly what to do in a situation such as that and it’d seem exactly as it is: too easy to figure out. On the other hand, it does give the player an opportunity to go back and do the other choice just for the fun of it and just to see what happens. It’s not really hard to get invested in what’s going on in Nova, the land this takes place in, but it’s just as easy not to.The art is a hit or a miss for me. The character designs are simple, but one of the characters, Julianna the Duchess of Ursul, reminds me almost completely of Sailor Mercury of “Sailor Moon”. It’s a little distracting.The backgrounds for the game are fine but, again, tend to be simple since the backgrounds don’t seem to change that often. There are places Elodie can go during the weekend, but there’s not a real immersion factor here although I’m sure that’s probably not intended.Often, it’s hard to determine how old the characters are (especially the older gentleman who sends Elodie a necklace, customary for betrothal) but it’s clear when they’re supposed to be young though it’s hard discerning whether they’re a teenager or not if one isn’t paying attention to the dialogue.More often than not, there’s almost unfinished feel with it. Granted, this game isn’t really meant to be something completely serious and, again as I mentioned before, it’s easy to not get as invested in it since there’s achievements for deaths. If you didn’t get the ending you want, it’s not like the game’s going to punish you – you’ll probably get an achievement out of it instead which could be beneficial if that’s what the player wanted.The music for the game fits it although maybe not the splash song. It’s a piano version of “God Save the Queen”, the British national anthem but the rest of the game’s music is fine. Of course, if the player doesn’t want the music, they could always turn it off in the preferences.As for the intrigue of Elodie’s mother’s demise, it’s pretty cut and dried. Based on the story itself when I got there, it’s so throwaway that her mother being dead might as well not have mattered.  From the way they alluded her mother’s death, I thought that this would finally get some deep stuff about the Lumens and why this world is the way it is (sort of modern but still in past fantasy/medieval) but it didn’t really end up that way, so that was disappointing.Perhaps it’s best that way though – if the entirety for the game is simple, there really isn’t any rhyme or reason why anything else would be more important than anything else. If there is any real intrigue, it’s about some of the preferences the dukes and duchesses have for company. Other than that, there’s no real intrigue. As mentioned over and over, this is pretty much cut & dried. It’s a simple story for a simple game about simply raising a princess named Elodie who may or may not become queen.It’s a fun ride, despite it all, and it certainly does have replay value even after the 100% achievements (epilogues, deaths, & achievements) have been unlocked. It’s not too deep and the art is cute although some people probably wouldn’t like it too much if they’re looking for a simulation with some depth to it. It is a fun game, though, and I’d recommend this to those who just want to try different things without worrying too much about the princess they’re trying to raise.

												A nice Dark Soul-ish game suitable for one sitting. Main complaint is the lack of diversity in ending, as there is only around one path to end it with too little variation. Many of the traits only have completionist uses, and since I tend to be more casual, this is also not a great quality. Also, the game is short, and I was expecting around at least twice as much main gameplay with restarts. Don't get me wrong, this was a thoroughly enjoyable game with a lot of thought put into the side missions. So if you like being a completionist or enjoy seeing all your hard work end abruptly (which IS humorous the first few times), or if you chust want to chill out to the AWESOMELY relaxing music, then this is a must.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Have you ever thought to yourself, "Gee I wonder what it would be like if I was Kawii Desu Nee-San anime Princess?" Well think no more my friend, for this game has the answer. It starts with you (Princess Kawaii) being pulled out of school by you father because your ♥♥♥♥♥ of a mother selfishly died. With her out of the picture, it becomes your duty to become the next princess. You do this by taking 2 different classes every week which in turn increase some of your skill levels. However this isn't like Skyrim where you can be a god at everything, instead you need to be a bit more carfull in what skill you want to increase.For example, if you wish to level up your intelect through history and diplomancy, you may be able to flatter that losser of a Prince after you remember his birthday. However in doing this you probably won't be skilled enough to dodge the arrow that just penetrated your Liver. Oh look, you're dead, try again...After you have completed your classes for the week, you than get see some more of the story unfold. It is also here where your learnt skills come into action, as they determin your success. You also get to make some choices in these events that ultimatly determin the fate of you and your kindom. There are also alot of pre-set events that you can't do anything about, so I wouldn't get to exited. My personal favourite event was when some peasent sent me a fanfiction of me having sex with a Squid.After these events you get the option of choosing an activity to do over the weekend, this affects your mood, which in turn affects how well you learn in your classes. Say if you are in an Angry mood, you will get a bounis in Swordfighting, but you will recive a penalty to Accounting. There are plenty of ways to play this game, however it can't can't give you endless enjoyment like 'Barbie Dollhouse Adventure' as after a few tries at the game, you notice that the story may be fairly linear. But that may have just been because I wasn't very imaginative with what actions I took during the game. I don't really have many dislikes with this game, possibably because I came in not expecting very much. One annoyance was that the only charater that shows any emotion at all is you. Also be prepared with the lore in this game, as there are heaps of Dukes and Duchesses which I couldn't be bothered to remember.I bought this game when it was on sale for $1.50 and I personally think $10 is a bit too much for this game. However if you buy it, it's a fairly fun little indie game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I know I don't have many hours into this game, but I NEEDED to get this review out of the way because I have a couple of things I need to say. This game is ♥♥♥♥ED UP. I took a small look at the Steam cards for the game, and they're all ways you can be murdered within the game with adorable pictures of our unnamed princess in various horrific ends to her life. My favorite being 'Run Through' which she has a shocked expression with a cutlass THROUGH HER CHEST. But don't worry, it's in a chibi type art style! So it's not too gruesome. That doesn't change the fact that this points out at least part of the game in centered around death, and the death of the main character. Hell, at the beginning her mother died. If she had the luck of her daughter, I couldn't imagine why.The exposition is fairly tame in a game you'd expect to take up your entire expierence before you just give up and play another game. The point of the game? It took me a while to figure out, but the princess is trying to be married. So you are NOT a queen, but that's just nitpicking. Firstly, I can't stand most of the canidates that she's supposed to take the hand of for marriage. I couldn't find an interesting one anywhere, and to be fair, the princess and her cousin (which is briefly killed off by a snake) are the only ones I found with personality. The rest of them are very..Emotionless. To be honest it matches their pictures in game pretty well.I do like the skill system in this game, very complex and the game keeps you thinking on which one you should train in next. One situation, you'll have to use reflexes to LIVE or you'll be screwed over because you don't have enough knowledge of foreign countries!...And it turns into a shoot and miss simulator. You just have to pray you trained in the right stuff. I love the art this game delivers though, of course I love the style, being anime and such. I mean I love anime, as you can see from my profile picture. Gameplay is simple, it's a strategy game that's not forgiving in any way. I've played a lot of unforgiving recently, Five Nights at Freddy's 2, Risk of Rain, Rogue Legacy, hell even Dark Souls 2 and this definitely amung those titles. Although I'm not sure with the difficulty spike in this game as the other titles follow (except Rogue Legacy that just starts out difficult). More of just an awkward curve before the game upright kills you.6.2/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Summary: Princess Maker without dungeonsMultiplayer: NoCompletion: 9 hrsCards: YesCloud: NoThe Princess Maker games are a series of time management games that never saw an official US release. Despite the obvious aim towards girls, they are enjoyable enough in their own right to appeal to broader audiences. A handful of indie games were inspired by them, and this is one such game.In Long Live the Queen, you spend each week selecting classes to raise your stats. Intermixed with the training are story events that take place throughout the game. Interestingly, there's nearly always something new happening every week, and the majority of events require stat checks in order to pass/fail. These checks are not telegraphed in any way, so the only way to know when to expect is to observe them happen, and then jot them down. These events are not random, so you can and must prepare accordingly, as the stat checks climb very high very fast. Because of the high stat reqs, it is ill-advised to spread your points thin, as you would soon be unable to pass anything. This sort of playstyle is a bit... odd. It nearly guarantees failure for any first time player because there's just no way to know when you might get shot or poisoned the first time around, and thus no way to know how to beat it.A rather odd amount of plot is devoted to political intrigue. The game throws dozens of names of countries and nobles at you, most of which you never see or meet. I find it difficult to care about the politics of other countries when I've never visited it nor met its citizens. The game would rather tell you two countries not getting along, rather than show you two people arguing in court. To help curtail the politics chatter, I would have liked more opportunities to interact with other NPCs. Maybe a gathering location such as a tavern for allies would have been nice.A few skills seem to be of remarkably little use, such as some weapon skills. There seems to be a heavy bias towards practicing your magic. I wanted to create a warrior queen who rules with justice and might, but it doesn't seem to be an option.Sadly this game does not possess the dungeon crawling aspect of some of the Princess Maker games. Thus the whole game boils down to your ability to play trial and error, as you aim to survive, and ultimately win. The dungeon crawler would have been a fantastic use of combat-related skills.Long Live the Queen is enjoyable enough, and I seem to be drawn to these sorts of time-management games. It's a curious exercise in optimization, and despite the high likelihood of dying, is very accessible and easy to pick up and play. I rate this a 7/10. Not bad at all, but could use a few cool touches.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												tl;dr If you like this kind of game (pick-your-own, number crunch-y, visual novel and kind of dating sim-like), it's a very nice example of what it is. Otherwise, you're probably not going to like it. Initially,I sucked at the game and hated it. Then, I used a couple of walkthroughs, lightbulb moment happened and now I quite like it. It's a text-based game with consequences, but it's not as straightforward as that.  If you're slightly mathsy: instead of 'do x and y will happen' it sometimes feels more like x + v + u * w means y is very likely to happen, and maybe z too if your character feels more depressed that day'. It makes it almost realistic. In a way. It's still not going to appeal to everyone, though. My pros:- Outcome engine well designed, and well-disguised, which prevents the game from feeling simplistic despite first appearances. - Art is cute. Music doesn't irritate me despite the repetitiveness.- The dating sim element is more interesting than most and doesn't feel tacky or forced. Except for the bit where she can get forced into marriage, of course, but I'm talking about gameplay here.- This is basically a quick hit if you like achievement mining. I like achievement mining. My cons:- It's a visual novel-style game. For many players unfamiliar with them, or maybe text-based RPG games, I think it's not going to feel that engaging. Having to scrutinise a balance sheet of skills every round might not be that appealing to some either. - Wasn't the most intuitive game for me - had to rely on walkthroughs until I actually understood how to not keep dying by week 20. But that's probably my fault. - In terms of replayability, it can get very repetitive after a while. But I'm on something like my 35th playthrough.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												I was excited that Steam had this game. I didn't think I'd find anything like it on Steam. I love dating and/or growing up simulation games, like Princess Maker 2, and RE:Alistair++, but you usually don't see them around much).Update for Steam awards and more detail.The game is in a similar vein to games like Princess Maker 2 and Spirited Heart. You spend time raising your combination of Elodie's many stats in hopes of keeping her alive (and as queen) until her coronation. Unless you're looking at a guide, you're going to die. A few times. There are many parts of the story where you have to meet certain skill checks (one of the achievements is for finding 11 ways to die. This means "poisoned", "stabbed", "drowned", not stabbed by 11 different people or missing 11 skill checks to drown.There's two really cool things to that, though: (1) they always tell you where you failed (or even partially pass) a skill check (not all fails kill you), so it adds to the replayability because you're curious about what you missed. But, it also doesn't give the exact numbers (IIRC), so you might not know exactly how much higher you need to make the skill. (2) For most of the situations that could kill you, there are either ways to avoid the situation altogether, or multiple ways to pass the scenario.For example:  Based on a skill check, you can get a choice on whether or not to eat poisoned food. If you fail that check, you don't get a choice--Elodie chooses to eat it. But, based on another skill check, she can be prevented from eating it. If that skill check fails, though, she eats it and gets poisoned. But, THEN there's a check for a different skill for you to counteract the poison.This means you definitely have to put some points in a few areas you might not think of, but it still gives you a lot of room to play Elodie as an overall character that you like. Want Elodie to be a pacifist? You don't need to know archery, but you'll probably want to know medicine.For that, I decided to suggest a category to nominate LLtQ in: "Replay to Win". I wanted it to be a category for those types of games where you usually start over to get ahead. Often times, those are visual novels, or games like Dead or Alive Xtreme 2 (where you have to repeat the 2-week vacation).

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												The game is fun, but very short and severely lacking. I beat it in less than a day.The game is basically like one of those old DOS command lines, but with a GUI. Instead of typing, for example/attackyou would click a dialog on screen that reads"Attack!"The story is mildly interesting, and mildly emotional. The dialogue gives you a good idea of what is going on. You can train Elodie in different skills. In one part of the game (minor spoilers, doesn't affect story) somebody sends you a box of chocolates that is poisoned. If Elodie is proficient in divination she will notice a bad omen and you will have the option of not eating the chocolates. If she has proficient knowledge in poison, medicine, or herbs she will be able to heal after ingesting the poison. If Elodie hasn't been trained in any of these things she will eat the chocolates and die.I really wish the game would continue past coronation. It is very fun and entertaining, some of the battles and dialogue is really intense and gets you going. It stops short, however. It would also be cool if there was more visual feedback. Instead of:"A fierce battle rages on. elodie makes lots of explosions with her magic and bodies fly everywhere" it would be cool if there were animations that showed these things happening. Sometimes the battles can be difficult to visualize and it takes you out of the moment.That being said the game is very fun to play and I definitely recommend it for those who like command line or RPG games. It is very fun and I enjoyed it very much.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												“Long Live the Queen” is a life simulation game that’s reminiscent towards games like “Princess Maker” in Japan.Primarily, the main goal is to have Elodie, the princess that the player has to “raise” and help her survive wars, potential threats, and ward off unwanted suitors before she could become queen at fifteen years old, who is considered as a legal adult in this time period.There are different classes Elodie could take – such as, conversations, royal demeanor, animal handling, history, economics, faith, military, athletics, agility, and much much more! The more classes she takes, the more her skills will rise. The more her skills rise, the better she can understand certain conversations to progress the story along. Of course, it’s completely up to the player on what kind of queen Elodie could be just based on the choices made alone. There really isn’t an end to the choices to choose from!One of the main things that brings people to this game is not just what kind of queen she would be but if she’s going to survive long enough to become a queen. There are various ways to die in this game and each one is actually part of the achievements – which is a unique thing about it since most games would try to prevent that from happening.There is a way to avoid dying, of course, but the player has to make sure that her skill set for certain actions are pretty much almost completely filled up.Another unique thing about this game is the mood system. For every mood that she is, there’s a penalty and there’s a bonus. Certain moods help boost up skills for whatever class the player chooses for her and others, well, not so much. There’s actually a penalty if the player makes Elodie take the wrong classes for a certain mood she’s in.There are outfits the player can unlock, so long as that particular subject is pretty well-balanced. These outfits help boost up that particular subject, especially if she’s in a war, a tournament, or at the gala, although more often than not, they’re just there to change up from her boarding school uniform.If Elodie does manage to survive to coronation, there are epilogues afterwards based on the choices that the player makes. They’re the literal result of what happens based on the player’s choices and decisions as a young fourteen year old girl trying to become a Queen.Not only does the epilogues come in what happened to Elodie and her subjects (if they’re involved in any way), but they come in beautiful drawings that’s similar to stained glass on the castle walls.But what do I think of it? I really enjoyed it! It’s a lot of fun and it’s fun to try to get the different endings and different deaths. There’s actually a checklist within the game itself to try to get all the achievements, deaths, and different epilogue stained glasses to try to vary the game experience up.While it does seem that the endings are endless, there are a few problems.Going over the game over and over, eventually, it starts to become extremely repetitive. Sometimes new menus and new choices pop up which could lead to different endings/results but eventually, the player might have to pass by that same choice and those same scenes again just to get to the choices that the player has to deviate from.It’s a little bit of a bore but there is the option to skip the text so it’s really not that bad. Once new text pops up, though, it stops so the player can read it. There is the option to go back and re-do the choices but it doesn’t work all the time, so be sure you know what you’re doing in terms of choices.The writing for the political intrigue is pretty basic for a life simulation game but, honestly, I’m not sure if that’s really a complaint or not. On one hand, the player would know exactly what to do in a situation such as that and it’d seem exactly as it is: too easy to figure out. On the other hand, it does give the player an opportunity to go back and do the other choice just for the fun of it and just to see what happens. It’s not really hard to get invested in what’s going on in Nova, the land this takes place in, but it’s just as easy not to.The art is a hit or a miss for me. The character designs are simple, but one of the characters, Julianna the Duchess of Ursul, reminds me almost completely of Sailor Mercury of “Sailor Moon”. It’s a little distracting.The backgrounds for the game are fine but, again, tend to be simple since the backgrounds don’t seem to change that often. There are places Elodie can go during the weekend, but there’s not a real immersion factor here although I’m sure that’s probably not intended.Often, it’s hard to determine how old the characters are (especially the older gentleman who sends Elodie a necklace, customary for betrothal) but it’s clear when they’re supposed to be young though it’s hard discerning whether they’re a teenager or not if one isn’t paying attention to the dialogue.More often than not, there’s almost unfinished feel with it. Granted, this game isn’t really meant to be something completely serious and, again as I mentioned before, it’s easy to not get as invested in it since there’s achievements for deaths. If you didn’t get the ending you want, it’s not like the game’s going to punish you – you’ll probably get an achievement out of it instead which could be beneficial if that’s what the player wanted.The music for the game fits it although maybe not the splash song. It’s a piano version of “God Save the Queen”, the British national anthem but the rest of the game’s music is fine. Of course, if the player doesn’t want the music, they could always turn it off in the preferences.As for the intrigue of Elodie’s mother’s demise, it’s pretty cut and dried. Based on the story itself when I got there, it’s so throwaway that her mother being dead might as well not have mattered.  From the way they alluded her mother’s death, I thought that this would finally get some deep stuff about the Lumens and why this world is the way it is (sort of modern but still in past fantasy/medieval) but it didn’t really end up that way, so that was disappointing.Perhaps it’s best that way though – if the entirety for the game is simple, there really isn’t any rhyme or reason why anything else would be more important than anything else. If there is any real intrigue, it’s about some of the preferences the dukes and duchesses have for company. Other than that, there’s no real intrigue. As mentioned over and over, this is pretty much cut & dried. It’s a simple story for a simple game about simply raising a princess named Elodie who may or may not become queen.It’s a fun ride, despite it all, and it certainly does have replay value even after the 100% achievements (epilogues, deaths, & achievements) have been unlocked. It’s not too deep and the art is cute although some people probably wouldn’t like it too much if they’re looking for a simulation with some depth to it. It is a fun game, though, and I’d recommend this to those who just want to try different things without worrying too much about the princess they’re trying to raise.

												A cross between interactive story and Princess Maker, this game puts you in charge of Princess Elodie. She is a 13 year old girl who's mother, the Queen, has just died and she now has a year to prepare for her coronation and rulership, as she'll take the throne at age 14. You decide what classes she takes each week, as she'll need certain skills to progress the story in certain ways. Maybe she'll know enough about Espionage to realize nobles are plotting against her? Or what if she doesn't know enough about Court Manners to know that necklace from a distance noble is a courting gift? Will she be able to survive an assassination attempt?With multiple different endings, fans of the Princess Maker series and interactive stories will definitely love this game.
